uh there's one problem with a normal way of moving a character in the game
because normally you you control the character with your controller and it moves the character and then it plays
the animation of like the feet moving or whatever and in approximately the
correct speed this leads very often to like the feet sliding on the ground and
if there's anything an animator hates it's sliding feet so we couldn't have that at least not if
you wanted to replace the hand animation animated look we had in the mini kids so
uh what we ended up using instead is uh something called root motion and this is a system where the
animation the movement of the character is baked into the animation so the
actually the animation itself actually moves the character along its path in space in space yeah yeah so the
character just follows along with with Run's animation yeah and that's good because then you get like the he moving
from side to side and all that little stuff that we would have lost if we have just moved him along yeah uh and the
feet are stuck to the ground which makes me happy yeah uh but it it's it is a little
harder to get the looping to work because it not only has to Loop in time but also in space so and uh it limits
speed changes a little bit but all in all it was a good way of doing it yeah
it looked much better when uh like my first prototype where he was just sliding and walking and rotating it
didn't look too good but he was so happy though yeah it worked but it would looked bad okay so um so we got him
moving that's that was good uh the next part of the puzzle was because fontas was actually going to be in the real world he he was going to look at real
Machinery film before like this was pre-recorded materials uh of like tractors or excavators or stuff uh so we
needed a way to see uh the actual video Behind fontas to to play AC him out in
in real time so on the on the screen you'll see sort of a composite of uh this is he he's this is font uh and this
he he walks inside this flattened Dome almost like a sphere that is flattened and onto this uh Dome we project the
video from the camera onto no matter where the virtual camera is we will always see the background and
then we have to match the the the camera position in unre to perspective to get
so the camera angle the camera width the camera height uh everything has to match and we do that by by hand and also we
have to set up lights so the sun shines in the correc way um to to get get him
sort of into the world where you can have shadows on the ground yeah um there was also one more thing that we got from
using and will is that we could use the voice recording from fontus the actor who played fontus and we took the voice
recording and we took the loudness of the audio file to drive the bone of his jaw so we could get like mouth movements
for free we didn't have to animate the Lip lip sync so we just let the actor play and then Fontes was just like blah
blah blah blah doing the same talk as the actor so that was a lot of uh work saved saved time yes definitely so and
